page.lettertext:
fol.31r
May it please yo
r
good L. Upon
e writing of my last of
e
21 and
e 22 heereof to yo
r
L. and to
S
r
Robert Cecyll
, I
was presently informed,
at
e
States
had a meaning, to
treate me to repaire w
t
their offer to her
Ma
tie
,
to
e
end they might be told [whereunto they must trust.]
For although
at I had written to understand her Hig
es
pleasure, about
e point of their intention, not to
tye themselves by
e Treatie to her Hig
es
heyres and
successo
rs
, yet they thought it very requisit, to
deale effectually and cleerly in every other pont
by delyvering unto me their Articles in writing,
to be wholly and particularly imparted unto her
that when their Deputies shalbe in
England
there
may be no exception against any one Article, which
they should be forced to returne as they came, wherof
they apprehend
at so great inconvenience may p
nt
ly
ensue, as they will not give
e adventure w
t
out
some certaintie before. If her Ma
tie
presuppose,
at
their Deputies shall come, w
t
suche sufficient comission
as it will be loste to their discretions, to treat of any
thing there, as occasion is ministred, or in any [other]
sort, then is precisely prescribed before they dep[art it]
is told me very flatly,
at it will not be permitted [and]
no man heere will be willing to goe w
t
suche Comisssion.
He
at made me thus privie to
e purpose of
e States
is
e partie knowen to yo
r
L. from whome
e Project came
at first, who when he had found me nothing willing
to depart from
e Hage, till I had heard out of England,
for
at her Ma
tie
might happilie upon
at w
ch
I had
written, enjoine me to doe somew
at
at might [aske my]
presence heere, he told me very earnestly, it was need-
full I should doe it, to drawe
e States by
at meanes
to exhibit unto me, their Agreement in writing,
which otherwise he was sure they would keepe unto
themselves, till I were readie to depart, and might
be moved then
e while, to make some further alte-
rations. Finding his advise to concurre in this
point, w
t
e opinion of others, and having prooved by
experience,
at some one newe devise of some one
ticklish Deputie, might suffise to marre as muche,
fol.31v
as had bin hitherto determined, and [that also other]
accidents might engender among th[em some back-]
[ward] discourses, I fell to take
is reso[lution that I]
would take my leave heere and goe p[resently for]
Zeland,
and there attend
e returne o[f the messen-]
ger I sent, and if any newe charge [were impo]
sed upon me, by order from her Ma
tie
a[t were of]
importance, and should requyre my p[resence here,]
I would returne upon it out of hand, [but if it]
might be perfourmed by
M
r
Gilpin
alo[ne, I would]
repaire unto her Ma
tie
w
t
all convenien[t expedition.]
I shall heereupon receave their offer in [writing,]
w
t
some letter of petition,
at her Ma
tie
wou[ld accept]
it, w
ch
when they have delivered, I wil[l from hence]
into Zeland, knowing no better waye to n[egotiat]
heerin, and finding it behoofull for sundri[e weightie]
considerations, before
e Deputies goe from h[ence, to]
informe her Ma
tie
very throughlie, of such[e .]
ties and pointes, in w
ch
there may be some [use of]
my knowledge and report.
And so I take [my humble leave]
From
e Hage March 24 95.
Posts
c
Yo
r
L. will be pleased to remember her Ma
tie
as I h[ave formerly]
advertised,
at there hath nothing bin delyvered [by me to]
e States in all my Treaties w
t
them, as if her Hig[
es
were ac-]
quainted w
t
e course of my dealing. Nor I [give no ap-]
probation to any part of their offer, in her be[half, but]
will onely take it as exhibited, to be presented [first by me]
and after by their Deputies, if she will accept [it,]
And in
at respect I thought it fitte, whether he[r Highnes]
lyke it or dislyke it, to have it in my custo[dy, to]
prevent suche further change as might [happily come .]
between. By co
m
unic
a
on heere w
t
some, I [do find]
at they could wishe,
at
e garrison of Flushing [were not]
left over weake by drawing away so many [men, not for]
any feare
at they have of
e Enemie, but to ta[ke away occa-]
sion from
e inhabitants of
e Towne of seeking [further]
libertie, w
ch
if it should happen, wherof the[y say]
notw
t
standing they have no maner of [suspicion,]
fol.32r
it might perhaps be impossible for
e State to recover
the place for her Ma
tie
againe. And so for
e
Brille
they say
e same.
